metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Add Grid Lines to a Plot
With Pyplot, you can use the grid() function to add grid lines to the plot.
content.html: With Pyplot, you can use the grid() function to add grid lines to the plot.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import numpy as npimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltx = np.array([80, 
  85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])y = np.array([240, 250, 260, 
  270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])plt.title("Sports Watch Data")
  plt.xlabel("Average Pulse")plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage")plt.plot(x, 
  y)plt.grid()plt.show()

content.code:
import numpy as npimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltx = np.array([80,
85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])y = np.array([240, 250, 260,
270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])plt.title("Sports Watch Data")
plt.xlabel("Average Pulse")plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage")plt.plot(x,
y)plt.grid()plt.show()

syntax_highlighting.text:
import numpy as npimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltx = np.array([80, 
 85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])y = np.array([240, 250, 260, 
 270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])plt.title("Sports Watch Data")
  plt.xlabel("Average Pulse")plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage")plt.plot(x,

content.code_html:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = np.array([80, 85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])
y = np.array([240, 250, 260, 270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])

plt.title("Sports Watch Data")
plt.xlabel("Average Pulse")
plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage")

plt.plot(x, y)

plt.grid()

plt.show()

  85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])y = np.array([240, 250, 260, 
  270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])plt.title("Sports Watch Data")
  plt.xlabel("Average Pulse")plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage")plt.plot(x, 
  y)plt.grid()plt.show()

content.text: Specify Which Grid Lines to Display
You can use the axis parameter in the grid() function to specify which grid lines to display.
content.html: You can use the axis parameter in the grid() function to specify which grid lines to display.

content.text: Legal values are: 'x', 'y', and 'both'. Default value is 'both'.
content.html: Legal values are: 'x', 'y', and 'both'. Default value is 'both'.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import numpy as npimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltx = np.array([80, 
  85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])y = np.array([240, 250, 260, 
  270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])plt.title("Sports Watch Data")
  plt.xlabel("Average Pulse")plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage")plt.plot(x, 
  y)plt.grid(axis = 'x')plt.show()

content.text: Set Line Properties for the Grid
You can also set the line properties of the grid, like this: grid(color = ' color ', linestyle = ' linestyle ', linewidth = number ).
content.html: You can also set the line properties of the grid, like this: grid(color = 'color', linestyle = 'linestyle', linewidth = number).

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import numpy as npimport matplotlib.pyplot as pltx = np.array([80, 
  85, 90, 95, 100, 105, 110, 115, 120, 125])y = np.array([240, 250, 260, 
  270, 280, 290, 300, 310, 320, 330])plt.title("Sports Watch Data")plt.xlabel("Average 
  Pulse")plt.ylabel("Calorie Burnage")plt.plot(x, 
  y)plt.grid(color = 'green', linestyle = '--', linewidth = 0.5)plt.show()
